repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Economic Reform Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Reform
            Technical Assistance Project in Sri Lanka were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included: the project team
            took client ownership very seriously, making a real effort
            to listen to officials and stakeholders and tailoring the
            project to their needs. In all areas, Sri Lankans called the
            shots and sought Bank technical advice only when necessary.
            The project incorporated an unallocated pool of resources,
            the Challenge Fund. Although initially received with a
            healthy degree of skepticism, the Challenge Fund has
            provided space for successive administrations to alter the
            course of the reforms and still be able to benefit from Bank
            funding without having to design a new project. It has also
            helped the Bank respond almost immediately with post-tsunami
            assistance. Realizing that each administration has a small
            window of opportunity to push reform initiatives, the Bank
            committed to a quick turnaround on all Technical Assistance
            (TA) requests and after initial teething problems was able
            to come to a two to three day turnaround for all requests.
            Establishing capacity to handle the procurement and
            management of more than 100 consultancies in the first two
            years of operation was critical to success. It also meant
            that line ministries could focus on management of the reform
            and leave the administrative aspects to others.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Economic Reform Technical
            Assistance Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Reform Technical Assistance
            Project will strengthen the government's capacity in
            implementing its reform agenda, which will in turn expand
            the role of the private sector in the economy, financing and
            supporting infrastructure development, in the water sector,
            and communications infrastructure. This would potentially
            entail wider environmental impacts, associated with both
            public, and private civil works, and construction. This
            framework for environmental screening sets the stage to
            identify environmental problems, and liabilities due to the
            implementation of the project, to further generate
            environmental compliance with the national laws. An
            environmental auditing process - Phase I and II which may be
            completed concurrently - should finally confirm the presence
            of specific forms of environmental liability. Phase I
            identifies site selection, aerial emissions, wastewater
            discharges, waste storage and disposal, as well as
            precautions to be taken due to hazardous materials, fire
            occurrence, and/or occupational health and safety issues.
            Phase II involve intrusive sampling of environmental issues,
            such as soils, groundwater and surface waters, and
            building/insulating materials. While it is anticipated that
            the auditing process will be sufficient, it is possible
            however, that significant contamination may occur, in which
            case a risk assessment may be required. The assessment
            involves the identification, quantification, and allocation
            of environmental liabilities. Monitoring criteria will be
            the responsibility of the implementing agency, based on
            institutional arrangements for the full compliance with the
            objectives set within this framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Economic Reform Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Reform Technical Assistance
            Project for Sri Lanka aims to stengthen the
            government's capacity to implement the economic reform
            agenda. This will be achieved by funding priority technical
            assistance that will provide government with the executive
            capacity required to implement its reform agenda. The
            implementation of the government's economic reforms
            will in turn expand the role of the private sector in the
            economy and put the country on the path of higher economic
            growth and faster poverty reduction. There are four project
            components. The first component strengthens the
            government's reform management capacity. The second
            component privatizes the People's Bank; provides
            technical assistance for the Asset Management Company;
            builds the capacity of the non-bank financial regulator;
            finances the establishment of the Pensions Reform Office,
            and supports private sector participation in the water
            sector; finds assistance to the Public Utilities Commission;
            and finances the regulatory framework for the
            telecommunications sector. The third component supports the
            design and implementation of a suitable mass communications
            strategy. The fourth component establishes and operates the
            Challenge Fund, which will manage a pool of technical
            assistance funds that can be flexibly allocated to
            sub-projects. This Fund will allow the relevant line
            ministries and government entities to respond flexibly to a
            dynamic and developing agenda.
